scenes.title: Arrival in Quadlings
scenes.summary: The travelers reach the beautiful country of the Quadlings.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXII The Country of the Quadlings
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the Quadlings.
scenes.text:
The country of the Quadlings seemed rich and happy. There was field
upon field of ripening grain, with well-paved roads running between,
and pretty rippling brooks with strong bridges across them. The fences
and houses and bridges were all painted bright red, just as they had
been painted yellow in the country of the Winkies and blue in the
country of the Munchkins. The Quadlings themselves, who were short and
fat and looked chubby and good-natured, were dressed all in red, which
showed bright against the green grass and the yellowing grain.
The Monkeys had set them down near a farmhouse, and the four travelers
walked up to it and knocked at the door. It was opened by the farmer's
wife, and when Dorothy asked for something to eat the woman gave them
all a good dinner, with three kinds of cake and four kinds of cookies,
and a bowl of milk for Toto.
"How far is it to the Castle of Glinda?" asked the child.
"It is not a great way," answered the farmer's wife. "Take the road to
the South and you will soon reach it."
Thanking the good woman, they started afresh and walked by the fields
and across the pretty bridges until they saw before them a very
beautiful Castle. Before the gates were three young girls, dressed in
handsome red uniforms trimmed with gold braid; and as Dorothy
approached, one of them said to her:
"Why have you come to the South Country?"
"To see the Good Witch who rules here," she answered. "Will you take me
to her?"
"Let me have your name, and I will ask Glinda if she will receive you."
They told who they were, and the girl soldier went into the Castle.
After a few moments she came back to say that Dorothy and the others

scenes.title: Preparation for Glinda
scenes.summary: Dorothy and friends prepare to meet Glinda.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXIII Glinda The Good Witch Grants Dorothy's Wish
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
Before they went to see Glinda, however, they were taken to a room of
the Castle, where Dorothy washed her face and combed her hair, and the
Lion shook the dust out of his mane, and the Scarecrow patted himself
into his best shape, and the Woodman polished his tin and oiled his
joints.
When they were all quite presentable they followed the soldier girl
into a big room where the Witch Glinda sat upon a throne of rubies.

characters.importance_exp: The characters are getting ready to meet Glinda, indicating its significance.
characters.quote: they were taken to a room of the Castle, where Dorothy washed her face and combed her hair, and the Lion shook the dust out of his mane, and the Scarecrow patted himself into his best shape, and the Woodman polished his tin and oiled his joints.

scenes.title: Meeting Glinda
scenes.summary: The group meets Glinda and shares their wishes.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXIII Glinda The Good Witch Grants Dorothy's Wish
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Glinda's throne room.
scenes.text:
She was both beautiful and young to their eyes. Her hair was a rich red
in color and fell in flowing ringlets over her shoulders. Her dress was
pure white but her eyes were blue, and they looked kindly upon the
little girl.
"What can I do for you, my child?" she asked.
Dorothy told the Witch all her story: how the cyclone had brought her
to the Land of Oz, how she had found her companions, and of the
wonderful adventures they had met with.
"My greatest wish now," she added, "is to get back to Kansas, for Aunt
Em will surely think something dreadful has happened to me, and that
will make her put on mourning; and unless the crops are better this
year than they were last, I am sure Uncle Henry cannot afford it."
Glinda leaned forward and kissed the sweet, upturned face of the loving
little girl.
"Bless your dear heart," she said, "I am sure I can tell you of a way
to get back to Kansas." Then she added, "But, if I do, you must give me
the Golden Cap."
"Willingly!" exclaimed Dorothy; "indeed, it is of no use to me now, and
when you have it you can command the Winged Monkeys three times."
"And I think I shall need their service just those three times,"
answered Glinda, smiling.
Dorothy then gave her the Golden Cap, and the Witch said to the
Scarecrow, "What will you do when Dorothy has left us?"
"I will return to the Emerald City," he replied, "for Oz has made me
its ruler and the people like me. The only thing that worries me is how
to cross the hill of the Hammer-Heads."
"By means of the Golden Cap I shall command the Winged Monkeys to carry
you to the gates of the Emerald City," said Glinda, "for it would be a
shame to deprive the people of so wonderful a ruler."
"Am I really wonderful?" asked the Scarecrow.
"You are unusual," replied Glinda.
Turning to the Tin Woodman, she asked, "What will become of you when
Dorothy leaves this country?"
He leaned on his axe and thought a moment. Then he said, "The Winkies
were very kind to me, and wanted me to rule over them after the Wicked
Witch died. I am fond of the Winkies, and if I could get back again to
the Country of the West, I should like nothing better than to rule over
them forever."
"My second command to the Winged Monkeys," said Glinda "will be that
they carry you safely to the land of the Winkies. Your brain may not be
so large to look at as those of the Scarecrow, but you are really
brighter than he is—when you are well polished—and I am sure you will
rule the Winkies wisely and well."
Then the Witch looked at the big, shaggy Lion and asked, "When Dorothy
has returned to her own home, what will become of you?"
"Over the hill of the Hammer-Heads," he answered, "lies a grand old
forest, and all the beasts that live there have made me their King. If
I could only get back to this forest, I would pass my life very happily
there."
"My third command to the Winged Monkeys," said Glinda, "shall be to
carry you to your forest. Then, having used up the powers of the Golden
Cap, I shall give it to the King of the Monkeys, that he and his band
may thereafter be free for evermore."

scenes.title: Goodbyes and Departure
scenes.summary: Dorothy says goodbye and returns home.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXIII Glinda The Good Witch Grants Dorothy's Wish
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Kansas.
scenes.text:
The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion now thanked the Good
Witch earnestly for her kindness; and Dorothy exclaimed:
"You are certainly as good as you are beautiful! But you have not yet
told me how to get back to Kansas."
"Your Silver Shoes will carry you over the desert," replied Glinda. "If
you had known their power you could have gone back to your Aunt Em the
very first day you came to this country."
"But then I should not have had my wonderful brains!" cried the
Scarecrow. "I might have passed my whole life in the farmer's
cornfield."
"And I should not have had my lovely heart," said the Tin Woodman. "I
might have stood and rusted in the forest till the end of the world."
"And I should have lived a coward forever," declared the Lion, "and no
beast in all the forest would have had a good word to say to me."
"This is all true," said Dorothy, "and I am glad I was of use to these
good friends. But now that each of them has had what he most desired,
and each is happy in having a kingdom to rule besides, I think I should
like to go back to Kansas."
"The Silver Shoes," said the Good Witch, "have wonderful powers. And
one of the most curious things about them is that they can carry you to
any place in the world in three steps, and each step will be made in
the wink of an eye. All you have to do is to knock the heels together
three times and command the shoes to carry you wherever you wish to
go."
"If that is so," said the child joyfully, "I will ask them to carry me
back to Kansas at once."
She threw her arms around the Lion's neck and kissed him, patting his
big head tenderly. Then she kissed the Tin Woodman, who was weeping in
a way most dangerous to his joints. But she hugged the soft, stuffed
body of the Scarecrow in her arms instead of kissing his painted face,
and found she was crying herself at this sorrowful parting from her
loving comrades.
Glinda the Good stepped down from her ruby throne to give the little
girl a good-bye kiss, and Dorothy thanked her for all the kindness she
had shown to her friends and herself.
Dorothy now took Toto up solemnly in her arms, and having said one last
good-bye she clapped the heels of her shoes together three times,
saying:
"Take me home to Aunt Em!"
Instantly she was whirling through the air, so swiftly that all she
could see or feel was the wind whistling past her ears.
The Silver Shoes took but three steps, and then she stopped so suddenly
that she rolled over upon the grass several times before she knew where
she was.
At length, however, she sat up and looked about her.
"Good gracious!" she cried.
For she was sitting on the broad Kansas prairie, and just before her
was the new farmhouse Uncle Henry built after the cyclone had carried
away the old one. Uncle Henry was milking the cows in the barnyard, and
Toto had jumped out of her arms and was running toward the barn,
barking furiously.
Dorothy stood up and found she was in her stocking-feet. For the Silver
Shoes had fallen off in her flight through the air, and were lost
forever in the desert.

scenes.title: Aunt Em's Garden
scenes.summary: Dorothy reunites with Aunt Em in the garden.
scenes.chapter: Chapter XXIV Home Again
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
Aunt Em had just come out of the house to water the cabbages when she
looked up and saw Dorothy running toward her.
"My darling child!" she cried, folding the little girl in her arms and
covering her face with kisses. "Where in the world did you come from?"
"From the Land of Oz," said Dorothy gravely. "And here is Toto, too.
And oh, Aunt Em! I'm so glad to be at home again!"

characters.name: Homecoming And Belonging
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as it highlights Dorothy's happiness upon returning home.
characters.quote: Oh, Aunt Em! I'm so glad to be at home again!

characters.name: Family Love
characters.importance_exp: The theme of family love is crucial as it showcases the bond between Aunt Em and Dorothy.
characters.quote: My darling child!

characters.name: Isolation And Desolation
characters.quote: When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around, she could see nothing but the great gray prairie on every side.
characters.explanation: This gray color reflects the themes of isolation and desolation, representing the bleakness of loneliness.

characters.name: Change And Aging
characters.quote: The sun and wind had changed her, too. They had taken the sparkle from her eyes and left them a sober gray.

characters.name: Hardship And Survival
characters.quote: Uncle Henry never laughed. He worked hard from morning till night and did not know what joy was.

characters.name: Danger And Threat
characters.quote: There's a cyclone coming, Em.

characters.name: Family And Community
characters.quote: Quick, Dorothy! Run for the cellar!

characters.name: Nature's Power And Beauty
characters.quote: There were lovely patches of greensward all about, with stately trees bearing rich and luscious fruits.
characters.explanation: This forest green color reflects nature's power and beauty, evoking the richness of the natural world.

characters.name: Fear And Anxiety
characters.quote: At first she had wondered if she would be dashed to pieces when the house fell again; but as the hours passed and nothing terrible happened, she stopped worrying and resolved to wait calmly and see what the future would bring.
characters.explanation: This vibrant red color symbolizes fear and anxiety, capturing the intensity of these emotions.

characters.explanation: This bright cyan color symbolizes freedom and liberation, representing the joy of breaking free.

characters.name: Gratitude

characters.explanation: This light peach color represents gratitude, evoking feelings of thankfulness and appreciation.

characters.name: Good Vs Evil
characters.quote: Oh, no, that is a great mistake. There were only four witches in all the Land of Oz, and two of them, those who live in the North and the South, are good witches.

characters.quote: In the civilized countries I believe there are no witches left, nor wizards, nor sorceresses, nor magicians.
characters.explanation: This rich purple color signifies magic and enchantment, representing the mystical elements of the story.

characters.name: Power And Authority

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty

characters.quote: Finally she picked up her basket. "Come along, Toto," she said. "We will go to the Emerald City and ask the Great Oz how to get back to Kansas again."

characters.name: Desire For Knowledge

characters.name: Desire For Home
characters.quote: I am sure I do not want to kill anybody, even to see Aunt Em again.

characters.name: Perseverance
characters.quote: We must certainly get to the Emerald City if we can," the Scarecrow continued.

characters.name: Bravery And Sacrifice

characters.name: Journey's End
characters.quote: "Yet it was afternoon before they came to the great wall that surrounded the City."

characters.quote: "Because if you did not wear spectacles the brightness and glory of the Emerald City would blind you."
characters.explanation: This deep purple color represents the theme of illusion versus reality, symbolizing mystery and depth.

characters.name: Wisdom And Guidance
characters.quote: "I am the Guardian of the Gates, and since you demand to see the Great Oz I must take you to his Palace."

characters.name: Color Symbolism
characters.quote: Even with eyes protected by the green spectacles, Dorothy and her friends were at first dazzled by the brilliancy of the wonderful City.

characters.name: Prosperity And Happiness
characters.quote: Everyone seemed happy and contented and prosperous.

characters.name: Authority And Power
characters.quote: "Here are strangers," said the Guardian of the Gates to him, "and they demand to see the Great Oz."

characters.name: Anticipation
characters.quote: They had to wait a long time before the soldier returned.

characters.name: Authority
characters.quote: He said he will grant you an audience, if you so desire; but each one of you must enter his presence alone.

characters.name: Transformation
characters.quote: "the green maiden came to fetch Dorothy, and she dressed her in one of the prettiest gowns, made of green brocaded satin."
characters.explanation: This indigo color symbolizes transformation, representing change and personal growth.

characters.name: Curiosity
characters.quote: "Are you really going to look upon the face of Oz the Terrible?"

characters.name: Courage And Weakness
characters.quote: "Because you are strong and I am weak; because you are a Great Wizard and I am only a little girl."

characters.name: Expectations And Bargains
characters.quote: "You have no right to expect me to send you back to Kansas unless you do something for me in return."

characters.name: Power And Responsibility
characters.quote: "I never killed anything, willingly."

characters.name: Surprise And Disillusionment

characters.quote: Bring me proof that the Wicked Witch is dead, and that moment I will give you courage.

characters.name: Nature's Beauty
characters.quote: walking over fields of soft grass dotted here and there with daisies and buttercups.

characters.name: Fatigue
characters.quote: Dorothy and Toto and the Lion were tired, and lay down upon the grass and fell asleep.

characters.name: Ineffectiveness Of Allies

characters.name: Victory Over Adversity
characters.quote: forty times a wolf was killed, so that at last they all lay dead in a heap before the Woodman.

characters.name: Power And Oppression
characters.quote: the Wicked Witch beat them well with a strap, and sent them back to their work.

characters.quote: She could not understand how all her plans to destroy these strangers had failed; but she was a powerful

characters.quote: So they set to work in one of the big yellow rooms of the castle and worked for three days and four nights, hammering and twisting and bending and soldering and polishing and pounding at the legs and body and head of the Tin Woodman, until at last he was straightened out into his old form, and his joints worked as well as ever.

characters.quote: Some of the Monkeys seized the Tin Woodman and carried him through the air until they were over a country thickly covered with sharp rocks.

characters.name: Courage
characters.quote: "I'll chop it down, and then we can get the Scarecrow's clothes."

characters.name: Comfort
characters.quote: "they found everything they needed to make them comfortable."

characters.quote: "We have surely lost our way," he said, "and unless we find it again in time to reach the Emerald City, I shall never get my brains."

characters.name: Beauty Vs. Utility

characters.name: Regret
characters.quote: I would not make you unhappy for all the world! exclaimed Dorothy. So I'll just say good-bye.

characters.name: Acceptance Of Self

characters.name: Perspective On Adversity

characters.quote: it was difficult to walk without falling into muddy holes

characters.quote: It is a most tremendous monster, like a great spider, with a body as big as an elephant and legs as long as a tree trunk.

characters.name: Loyalty

characters.quote: they were taken to a room of the Castle, where Dorothy washed her face and combed her hair, and the Lion shook the dust out of his mane, and the Scarecrow patted himself into his best shape, and the Woodman polished his tin and oiled his joints.

characters.quote: What can I do for you, my child? she asked.

locations.name: Kansas Prairies
locations.quote: Dorothy lived in the midst of the great Kansas prairies, with Uncle Henry, who was a farmer, and Aunt Em, who was the farmer's wife.

locations.name: Inside The House
locations.quote: Dorothy caught Toto at last and started to follow her aunt. When she was halfway across the room there came a great shriek from the wind, and the house shook so hard that she lost her footing and sat down suddenly upon the floor.

locations.name: On The Journey
locations.quote: The little girl gave a cry of amazement and looked about her, her eyes growing bigger and bigger at the wonderful sights she saw.

locations.name: Land Of Oz
locations.quote: You are welcome, most noble Sorceress, to the land of the Munchkins. We are so grateful to you for having killed the Wicked Witch of the East, and for setting our people free from bondage.

locations.name: Yellow Brick Road
locations.quote: There were several roads nearby, but it did not take her long to find the one paved with yellow bricks.

locations.name: Forest
locations.quote: All this time Dorothy and her companions had been walking through the thick woods. The road was still paved with yellow brick, but these were much covered by dried branches and dead leaves from the trees, and the walking was not at all good.

locations.name: Gulf Edge
locations.quote: The group camps for the night, faces dangers from the Kalidahs, and prepares to cross a river.

locations.name: River
locations.quote: They left the cottage and walked through the trees until they found a little spring of clear water, where Dorothy drank and bathed and ate her breakfast.

locations.name: Poppy Field
locations.quote: The travelers face challenges crossing a river, where the Stork rescues the Scarecrow, and later navigate a dangerous meadow of poppies.

locations.name: Underneath A Clump Of Grass
locations.quote: The Tin Woodman rescues a royal mouse, builds a truck for the Lion, and the mice help transport him before departing.

locations.name: Green Fields
locations.quote: The Munchkins were good farmers and able to raise large crops. Once in a while she would pass a house, and the people came out to look at her and bow low as she went by.

locations.name: Beside The Lion
locations.quote: The Lion and Scarecrow encourage each other to be brave in the face of danger.

locations.name: Emerald City Palace
locations.quote: Dorothy and her friends arrive at the Emerald City, meet Oz, and learn they must defeat the Wicked Witch to fulfill their wishes.

locations.name: Wicked Witch's Castle
locations.quote: Dorothy and her friends face various attacks from the Wicked Witch and her minions, culminating in the Witch's demise when Dorothy accidentally melts her.

locations.name: Rocky Plain
locations.quote: The travelers face the Hammer-Heads and then arrive in the enchanting land of the Quadlings.

locations.name: Tall Tree
locations.quote: The Scarecrow spots a cottage for shelter.

locations.name: Yellow Castle
locations.quote: The travelers explore the enchanting China Country, meeting its unique inhabitants and experiencing their whimsical world.

locations.name: On Top Of The Wall
locations.quote: The travelers face challenges in a marshland, discover a magical forest, witness a gathering of wild animals, and see the Lion defeat a spider monster, earning his title as the King of the forest.

locations.name: Church
locations.quote: Dorothy and her companions mourn their losses and prepare for their journey south, facing challenges like the fighting trees along the way.

locations.name: Disagreeable Country
locations.quote: The travelers face challenges and confusion while trying to escape the clutches of the Wicked Witch and continue their journey to the Emerald City.
